text: Artificial general intelligence, or AGI,
describes a type of artificial intelligence that matches
or surpasses human capabilities across most or even all cognitive tasks.
But AGI ...
well, it doesn't actually exist.
It's a theoretical AI system.
It's it's science fiction.
But many AI labs are bullish on AGI, indicating it's a matter of when, not if.
So in this video, let's consider a world
where AGI is here and ask ourselves how would that change things?
So we're going to explore eight use cases where AGI is applied.
And while we're at it, we'll also look at specific areas where today's AI needs to improve
to be able to achieve these capabilities.
So let's get started with number one,
and that is how AGI will affect customer service.
Now an AGI powered customer service system would access vast customer data
and combine it with real time analytics for personalized service.
What sort of vast customer data are we talking about?
Well, things like past experiences or buying habits and your client needs.
AGI might anticipate problems, tailor responses and suggest solutions,
and even predict follow up questions.
AGI could offer a perception system that anticipates potential issues,
uses tone analysis to better understand the customer's mood,
and possesses a keen memory that can recall the most specific minutia for that client.
Also, its emotional intelligence would allow it to adapt communication
to be empathetic and supportive, which
I think we can all agree is a far cry from today's automated systems.
Now, second, we need to think about how this would affect coding intelligence.
Now, AGI would grasp the logic and purpose of existing code bases,
suggesting improvements in generating new code based on human specifications.
So consider I'm building a new e-commerce feature.
Well, the programmer tells the AGI,
I need a function that will calculate shipping costs,
and it needs to be based on location and weight and methods.
Now, today's frontier AI models could already take a pretty good stab at a request like that,
but an AGI AI system would have a deep understanding of architecture,
dependencies, and change history, leading to better tailored code
ready for the programmer to review, optimize, and integrate.
All right, next up, current self-driving cars and autonomous systems rely heavily on
preprogramed maps and sensors, but that is beginning to change.
So how will AGI affect autonomous vehicles and autonomous transportation?
Well, AGI wouldn't just perceive its surroundings, it would understand them.
It might analyze real time data from cameras, lidar and
other sensors to identify objects, assess risks and anticipate environmental changes like
sudden weather events or unexpected obstacles,
and to do so in ways that are similar to the way that we do them.
So to recognize when another driver is waving us through at a four way stop,
or to better understand the intentions of other road users,
AGI might also assist in navigation, choosing the most effective
and safest route in real time.
Now, number four, that one is all about health care and how AGI could affect that.
Now, the vast amount of medical data generated today remains largely untapped.
AGI might analyze medical images, patient records, and genetic data
to identify subtle patterns that might escape human attention.
AGI might also analyze a patient's genetic makeup and medical history to tailor treatment plans.
And it's that personalized approach that might lead
to more effective therapies with fewer side effects.
Now, before I get to the other four use cases here,
let's pause for a moment to consider the ways that today's current AI systems
need to improve in order to reach AGI.
And the first thing we're going to need,
or certainly one of the things we're going to need, is better visual perception.
Now, computer vision has overcome some significant hurdles
in facial recognition and object detection, but it's still falls
far short of human capabilities in context and objects identification.
Multimodal AI models,
they're making a lot of progress here, but there's still a ways to go.
And similarly we'll need improvements in audio as well.
So audio perception also needs to improve.
AI systems are rapidly improving in speech recognition,
but they still struggle with things like regional accents or sarcasm
or identifying emotional tones.
Today's AI systems excel at something already, which is problem solving,
but they only do that to a certain extent.
It's primarily for well defined problems,
but an AGI would need to solve problems the way a human would
with reasoning and with critical thinking.
The AGI would need to handle uncertainty
and make decisions with incomplete information.
And look, human intelligence is deeply intertwined
with our emotional and our social abilities.
So an AGI would need those, too.
It's really what makes us us.
So an AGI would need to recognize and understand emotions,
including interpreting facial expressions, body language, and tone of voice.
But when we get all of that, what will it mean for our remaining use cases?
Well, look, I work in education, so this one is quite close to my heart.
Imagine an AGI tutor who doesn't present information
but personalizes the learning journey.
AGI might analyze the students performance,
learning style, and knowledge gaps to create a customized learning path.
It wouldn't treat all students the same.
AGI might adjust the pace and the difficulty of the material
in real time based on the students understanding.
So struggling with a concept?
AGI provides other explanations and examples.
Or if you're mastering a topic, it can introduce more challenging material.
All of which might not be great for my future job security,
but can AGI write backwards on a lightboard?
Can it?
All right, next up, next one, that is manufacturing.
Are you watching, AGI?
Look at that.
Okay, now, AGI might revolutionize manufacturing
by optimizing every step of the process.
By analyzing vast amounts of data from sensors on the production line.
It might recommend adjustments to machine settings
and optimize production schedules in real time for maximum efficiency.
Analyzing historical data and sensor readings might help AGI predict
equipment failures before they happen.
A slight vibration in the critical machine would be immediately recognized.
It would be analyzed and it would be addressed.
All right, two more.
Let's consider how this could affect financial services.
And the question we all want to know is: could AGI be the ultimate stock picker?
Well, it could analyze vast data sets encompassing financial news,
social media sentiment and even satellite imagery
to identify complex market trends and potential disruptions
that might go unnoticed by human analysts.
AGI might develop its own complex trading algorithms
that factor in this data to create more accurate financial models.
And finally, there is a R & D, or research and development,
which is possibly the most impactful use case of all.
Using all that it has learned, AGI might be able to formulate new hypotheses
and design experiments at an unprecedented scale,
accelerating scientific breakthroughs across all sorts of fields.
This would allow scientists to test hypotheses more efficiently
and explore previously unimaginable frontiers.
Look, AGI might be science fiction for now,
but we've made some massive advancements in AI in the past few years.
So when AGI does arrive, it is helpful if we've already considered some of the ways
we can take full advantage of it.
